slides.title: The Art of Problem Formulation
slides.content:
# Problem Formulation ğŸ¯

The most critical skill in data science isn't algorithmsâ€”it's **asking the right questions**.

## What You'll Learn
- **Business Understanding** - Translate business needs to data problems
- **Problem Definition** - Frame problems precisely
- **Success Metrics** - Define what "success" looks like
- **Stakeholder Management** - Work effectively with decision-makers

> ğŸ’¡ **Insight:** A well-defined problem is 50% solved!

## Why Problem Formulation Matters

| Scenario | Outcome |
|----------|--------|
| Good problem, weak algorithm | Often succeeds |
| Weak problem, good algorithm | Usually fails |

## The Cost of Poor Framing

- âŒ 70% of data science projects fail
- âŒ Main cause: Misalignment with business needs
- âŒ Wasted time building wrong solutions

Let's learn to get it right from the start!

slides.title: Business Understanding
slides.content:
# Business Understanding ğŸ’¼

Before writing any code, deeply understand the business context.

## Key Questions to Ask

### About the Business
- What does the company do?
- Who are the customers?
- What are the revenue streams?
- What competitive pressures exist?

### About the Problem
- Why is this problem important NOW?
- What happens if we don't solve it?
- How is it currently being addressed?
- What decisions will this analysis inform?

### About Constraints
- What's the timeline?
- What budget/resources are available?
- Are there regulatory considerations?
- What data is available?

## The 5 Whys Technique

| Level | Question | Answer |
|-------|---------|--------|
| 1 | Why do we need this? | Sales are declining |
| 2 | Why are sales declining? | Customer churn is high |
| 3 | Why is churn high? | Customers are dissatisfied |
| 4 | Why are they dissatisfied? | Product doesn't meet needs |
| 5 | Why doesn't it meet needs? | We don't understand usage patterns |

> ğŸ¯ **Root Cause:** We need usage analytics, not just a churn model!

slides.title: From Business to Data Problem
slides.content:
# Translating Business to Data Problems ğŸ”„

The key skill is converting vague business needs into precise analytical questions.

## Business vs Data Problem

| Business Problem | Data Science Problem |
|-----------------|--------------------|
| "Reduce customer churn" | Predict which customers will churn in 30 days |
| "Increase sales" | Recommend products to increase basket size |
| "Improve efficiency" | Forecast demand to optimize inventory |
| "Better customer service" | Classify support tickets by priority |

## Problem Type Identification

### Prediction Problems
- **Classification:** Is this email spam or not?
- **Regression:** What will be the house price?

### Pattern Discovery
- **Clustering:** What customer segments exist?
- **Association:** What products are bought together?

### Optimization
- **Scheduling:** What's the best route?
- **Allocation:** How to distribute resources?

## Framework: SMART Goals

| Letter | Meaning | Example |
|--------|---------|--------|
| S | Specific | Predict customer churn |
| M | Measurable | With 85% accuracy |
| A | Achievable | Using available data |
| R | Relevant | To reduce churn by 20% |
| T | Time-bound | By end of Q2 |

> ğŸ’¡ **Tip:** Always clarify: "What decision will change based on this analysis?"

slides.title: Problem Definition Framework
slides.content:
# Problem Definition Framework ğŸ“‹

Use a structured template to define every data science problem.

## The Problem Statement Template

### 1. Context
> "Currently, [describe the situation and why it matters]"

### 2. Problem
> "The problem is [specific issue to be solved]"

### 3. Impact
> "This costs us [quantifiable impact: money, time, customers]"

### 4. Success Criteria
> "We will have solved this when [measurable outcome]"

### 5. Constraints
> "We must work within [limitations: time, data, resources]"

## Example: E-commerce Recommendation

| Section | Content |
|---------|--------|
| Context | Our e-commerce platform has 10M products |
| Problem | Customers can't find relevant products |
| Impact | 40% cart abandonment rate |
| Success | Increase click-through rate by 15% |
| Constraints | Must work with existing infrastructure |

## Anti-Patterns to Avoid

- âŒ "We need AI" (solution before problem)
- âŒ "Analyze all our data" (too vague)
- âŒ "Build a dashboard" (output, not outcome)
- âŒ "Predict everything" (scope creep)

> ğŸ¯ **Golden Rule:** If you can't explain the problem in one sentence, you don't understand it yet.

slides.title: Success Metrics
slides.content:
# Defining Success Metrics ğŸ“Š

Without clear metrics, you can't know if you've succeeded.

## Types of Metrics

### Business Metrics
What the business cares about:
- Revenue increase
- Cost reduction
- Customer satisfaction (NPS)
- Conversion rate

### Model Metrics
How we measure model performance:
- Accuracy, Precision, Recall
- RMSE, MAE
- AUC-ROC

### Connecting Them

| Business Metric | Model Metric | Relationship |
|-----------------|-------------|-------------|
| Reduce fraud losses | Precision | Higher precision = fewer false alarms |
| Catch all fraud | Recall | Higher recall = fewer missed frauds |
| Customer churn | F1-Score | Balance precision and recall |

slides.title: Baseline Establishment
slides.content:
# Establishing Baselines ğŸ“

Before building complex models, know your baseline!

## Why Baselines Matter

- ğŸ“Š Measures improvement objectively
- ğŸ¯ Sets realistic expectations
- ğŸ’¡ Sometimes simple solutions work!
- âš ï¸ Prevents over-engineering

## Common Baseline Types

### 1. Random/Naive Baseline
- Always predict the most common class
- Always predict the mean value

### 2. Rule-based Baseline
- Simple business rules
- Heuristics from domain experts

### 3. Current Solution Baseline
- How the problem is solved today
- Manual processes or existing models

## Example: Churn Prediction

```python
# Baseline calculation
data = [0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0]  # 1 = churned

# Naive baseline: predict no churn
correct = sum(1 for x in data if x == 0)
total = len(data)
baseline_accuracy = correct / total

print(f"Baseline accuracy: {baseline_accuracy:.0%}")
```

slides.title: Stakeholder Management
slides.content:
# Stakeholder Management ğŸ¤

Data science doesn't happen in isolationâ€”success requires stakeholder alignment.

## Key Stakeholders

| Stakeholder | Interest | Communication |
|-------------|----------|---------------|
| **Executive Sponsor** | ROI, strategic alignment | High-level summaries |
| **Business Owner** | Problem resolution | Regular updates |
| **End Users** | Usability, trust | Training, feedback |
| **IT/Engineering** | Integration, maintenance | Technical specs |
| **Legal/Compliance** | Risk, regulations | Documentation |

## The RACI Matrix

| Activity | Sponsor | Business | Data Science | IT |
|----------|---------|----------|--------------|----|
| Define problem | C | R | A | I |
| Provide data | I | C | A | R |
| Build model | I | C | R | C |
| Deploy | A | I | C | R |

**R** = Responsible, **A** = Accountable, **C** = Consulted, **I** = Informed

## Managing Expectations

### What to Communicate
- âœ… Realistic timelines
- âœ… Data requirements
- âœ… Limitations and uncertainties
- âœ… Progress and blockers

### What to Avoid
- âŒ Over-promising results
- âŒ Technical jargon with non-technical stakeholders
- âŒ Surprises at the end

> ğŸ¯ **Golden Rule:** No technical surprisesâ€”communicate early and often!

slides.title: Scoping and Prioritization
slides.content:
# Scoping and Prioritization ğŸ¯

Not every problem should be solved with data science.

## The Feasibility Assessment

### Technical Feasibility
- Is sufficient data available?
- Is the problem predictable?
- Do we have the skills?

### Business Feasibility
- Is the ROI positive?
- Are stakeholders committed?
- Can we act on insights?

### Ethical Feasibility
- Are there fairness concerns?
- Privacy implications?
- Potential for misuse?

## Prioritization Matrix

| | High Impact | Low Impact |
|---|---|---|
| **Low Effort** | ğŸ† Quick Wins | â³ Fill-ins |
| **High Effort** | ğŸ¯ Strategic | âŒ Avoid |

## Minimum Viable Model (MVM)

### Phase 1: Prove Value
- Simple model, quick delivery
- Validate problem framing
- Get stakeholder buy-in

### Phase 2: Improve
- Add complexity gradually
- Iterate based on feedback
- Scale as needed

> ğŸ’¡ **Pro Tip:** Start with the smallest version that proves value, then iterate!

slides.title: Documentation Best Practices
slides.content:
# Documentation Best Practices ğŸ“

Good documentation ensures project continuity and stakeholder alignment.

## Project Charter Template

### Executive Summary
- Problem statement (1-2 sentences)
- Proposed solution
- Expected impact

### Background
- Business context
- Current state
- Why now?

### Objectives
- Primary goal
- Secondary goals
- Out of scope

### Success Criteria
- Business metrics
- Technical metrics
- Acceptance criteria

### Approach
- Data sources
- Methodology
- Timeline

### Risks
- Technical risks
- Business risks
- Mitigation strategies

### Resources
- Team members
- Budget
- Infrastructure

## Living Documentation

| Document | Update Frequency |
|----------|------------------|
| Project Charter | At milestones |
| Technical Specs | During development |
| Model Cards | At deployment |
| Runbooks | As processes change |

> ğŸ“‹ **Remember:** Documentation is for future you and your teammates!

slides.title: Case Study: Retail Optimization
slides.content:
# Case Study: Retail Optimization ğŸ›’

Let's apply our framework to a real scenario.

## The Business Request
> "We want to use AI to increase sales."

## Problem Formulation Process

### Step 1: Ask Questions
- **What products?** â†’ All products, focus on high-margin items
- **What channels?** â†’ Online store
- **Current situation?** â†’ 2.3% conversion rate, $45 average order
- **Why now?** â†’ Competition is gaining market share

### Step 2: Define the Problem
> "Increase online conversion rate by recommending relevant products to browsing customers"

### Step 3: Set Metrics

| Level | Metric | Target |
|-------|--------|--------|
| North Star | Revenue | +15% |
| Primary | Conversion Rate | 2.3% â†’ 3.0% |
| Secondary | Average Order Value | $45 â†’ $55 |
| Model | Click-through Rate | +20% |

### Step 4: Establish Baseline
- Current: Random product suggestions
- Baseline CTR: 1.2%

### Step 5: Define Scope
- **In scope:** Product recommendations on homepage
- **Out of scope:** Email recommendations, in-store

> ğŸ¯ **Result:** Clear, measurable problem with defined success criteria!

slides.title: Common Mistakes
slides.content:
# Common Problem Formulation Mistakes âš ï¸

Learn from others' mistakes!

## Mistake 1: Solution-First Thinking

âŒ **Wrong:** "Let's build a neural network"
âœ… **Right:** "What problem are we solving?"

## Mistake 2: Scope Creep

âŒ **Wrong:** "While we're at it, let's also..."
âœ… **Right:** "Let's finish phase 1 first"

## Mistake 3: Ignoring Constraints

âŒ **Wrong:** "We can collect any data we need"
âœ… **Right:** "What data do we have access to today?"

## Mistake 4: Unmeasurable Goals

âŒ **Wrong:** "Make customers happier"
âœ… **Right:** "Increase NPS from 32 to 45"

## Mistake 5: Stakeholder Misalignment

âŒ **Wrong:** Build in isolation, present at the end
âœ… **Right:** Regular check-ins and feedback loops

## Mistake 6: Overcomplicating

âŒ **Wrong:** Start with ensemble of 10 models
âœ… **Right:** Start with logistic regression baseline

## The Reality Check Questions

| Question | Good Answer |
|----------|------------|
| Who will use this? | Specific user/team |
| What decision will change? | Concrete action |
| How will we know it worked? | Measurable metric |

> ğŸ’¡ **Wisdom:** Simple solutions to well-defined problems beat complex solutions to vague problems!
